problem: A dilation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} -12 \\ -21 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the dilation take $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$ to?
solution: Since $(-3) \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -12 \\ -21 \end{pmatrix},$ the scale factor of the dilation is $-3.$  So the vector $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -15 \end{pmatrix}}.$
model_solution:
Step 1:  To solve this problem, we can first determine the scale factor of the dilation by comparing the corresponding components of the original and image vectors.
$\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to $\begin{pmatrix} -12 \\ -21 \end{pmatrix}$, so we divide the coordinates of the image point by the coordinates of the original point to find the scale factor.
$\begin{array}{rcl} \text{Scale Factor} &=& \frac{-12}{4}=\frac{-21}{7} \\ &=&-3 \end{array}$
Step 2:  Since we have determined that the scale factor is $-3,$ the dilation takes $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ -15 \end{pmatrix}.$
The dilation takes $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ -15 \end{pmatrix}}$.
The dilation takes $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ -15 \end{pmatrix}$.
Step 3: $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ -15 \end{pmatrix}$
The dilation takes $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ -15 \end{pmatrix}.$
The dilation takes $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ -15 \end{pmatrix}}$.
